Award.AwardTitle: Workshop on Ultra-Wide Band Gap (UWBG) Semiconductors: Research Opportunities and Directions- April 25-26, 2016, Arlington VA

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration: The proposed project seeks financial support for organizing a Workshop on the status and challenges of a broad class of semiconductors with bandgaps larger than 3.4 eV, i.e., larger than the bandgap of GaN. Representative materials are AlGaN (including the binary endpoint AlN), diamond, Ga2O3, and their heterostructures. The Workshop will be held April 25-26, 2016 at the Basic Research Innovation and Collaboration Center (BRICC) in Arlington VA. The Workshop will foster advances in the leading research of extreme (ultra) wide-bandgap (UWBG) semiconductors by gathering a diverse group of experts. Topics to be addressed include among other bulk and epitaxial growth, electronic transport at low and high fields, device architectures, heterostructure designs, fundamental limits to device performance, device fabrication and processing techniques, The workshop will include 7 invited talks, 10 contributed presentations and is expected to be attended by 70 attendees from industry, academia, and government. The organizing committee will select topic leads to assist with selection of attendees. The report prepared on the Workshop will summarize the outcome of the discussions and will be available to all the workshop attendees, as well as other members of the scientific community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Wide band gap semiconductors such as GaN and SiC are making significant technological impact in areas such as communication, lighting, sensing, and power conversion. Ultra wide bandgap semiconductors with bandgaps exceeding GaN/SiC, such as ultra wide band gap AlGaN alloys, promise even greater device peroformance and functionality. Representative materials are AlGaN (including the binary endpoint AlN), diamond, Ga2O3, and their heterostructures. Recently there has been significant interest in the science and applications of these materials, which could have impact in several areas including emitters, power electronics, and communications.


A workshop was organized to discuss and review the potential opportunities and challenges of such semiconductor materials. The workshop was attanded by over 60 experts, and led to the writing of an approximately 50-page review article that lays out the future research needs for UWBG semiconductors . The report included contributions from numerous institutions, and is organized around the themes of Materials, Physics, and Devices and Applications. Recommendations for future research are summarized in 26 Research Opportunities/Challenges divided amongst these three topics. The report also includes what is believed to be the most up-to-date list of material parameters for WBG and UWBG semiconductors. It is hoped that this report and its constituent research recommendations will guide future work in the field.
